title: Brexit's impact compared to 9/11 terror attacks by Bank of England expert
text:
News Brexit's impact compared to 9/11 terror attacks by Bank of England expert Ian McCafferty, who sits on the powerful Monetary Policy Committee, said leaving the EU was a "once in a lifetime event... such as 9/11" Share Theresa May is not going to like this one (Photo: REUTERS) Share Get politics   Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
A top Bank of England official compared Brexit to the September 11 terror attacks today. 
Ian McCafferty, who sits on the powerful interest rate-setting Monetary Policy Committee, likened the impact of the EU Leave vote to the 2001 atrocities which killed nearly 3,000 people. 
Explaining why polls of firms may have signalled they lost confidence in the immediate aftermath of June’s Out result, he claimed it was a “once in a lifetime event … such as 9/11”. 
He told the Treasury Select Committee he would “class the referendum result as an unusual if not almost unique shock to the economy in the sense that it only happens once in a lifetime or once in a generation”. Read More Theresa May piles pressure on Lords over Brexit bill by watching the debate from a golden throne 
Mr McCafferty, a former chief economic adviser at the Confederation of Business Industry, added: “I think we’ve seen some other different but similar unusual shocks such as 9/11, such as the East Asian crisis of 1997 and so on and so forth. Ian McCafferty said both events could be counted as "unusual shocks" (Photo: PA) 
“At those specific periods, over the very short term, business surveys can give you somewhat misleading signals.” 
Senior Bank officials were repeatedly quizzed by MPs over their failure to foresee the 2007/8 financial crash. 
But MPC member Gertjan Vlieghe warned “unrealistic expectations” were placed on economics and forecasting models. 
He gloomily admitted: “We are probably not going to forecast the next financial crisis nor are we going to forecast the next recession. 
“Models are just not that good.” The Bank of England expert compared the impact of Brexit to that of 9/11 (Photo: Getty) 
Chief economist Andy Haldane previously described the 2007/8 crash as the Bank’s “Michael Fish” moment. 
The BBC weatherman’s infamous October 1987 forecast saw him wrongly deny claims a hurricane was going to hit Britain, adding: “But it will be very windy in Spain.” 
Hours later, the Great Storm battered the UK, wreaking devastation that claimed 18 lives. 
Mr Haldane again admitted the Bank made a “very significant forecasting error,” but added it was important officials learned from mistakes. 
But committee chairman Andrew Tyrie said: “If there’s one view I have about forecasts is that it’s going to be wrong in economics, and usually very wrong. 
“I’m a deep sceptic about the scope for long-running improvements.” Committee chairman Andrew Tyrie said predictions were "usually wrong" (Photo: Rex) 
Bank Governor Mark Carney tried to defend the Bank’s predictions over Brexit , insisting: “Do we have a perfect model of the British household? No. 
“We might understand that no forecast as a prediction is perfect, that there’s probabilities around that, but that’s not what people hear, and we need to do a better job of explaining.” 
He believed the Bank had not received enough credit for its emergency actions in the aftermath of the referendum. 
Following the bombshell result, interest rates were slashed to their lowest ever level of 0.25% and £60billion was pumped into the economy. 
“If we hadn’t done that there would have been macro-economic consequences. It was important we did it and we just have to accept we are never going to get any credit for it, but I’m glad we did it,” he said. Like us on Facebook
